awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  Impacts of Convective and Stratiform Processes on Tropical Cyclone Intensity Change
awd_abstract_narration:
This study will investigate the impacts of convective and stratiform processes on tropical cyclone (TC) intensity change through analysis of mesoscale observations, with a focus on aircraft and Doppler radar data. Our ability to skillfully predict changes in TC intensity is still limited, but recent studies have suggested that the radial location of deep convective bursts and stratiform precipitation relative to the radius of maximum wind (RMW) may play an important role in intensification efficiency. Testing these new hypotheses using mesoscale observations is needed to diagnose the most important physical processes responsible for intensity change and improve TC intensity forecasts.

Intellectual Merit:
Analysis of Doppler radar, dropsonde, satellite, and other observations will be used to examine TC convective and stratiform structures, their thermodynamic and dynamic environment, and their impacts on the TC circulation. Previous theoretical and numerical studies have suggested that convective heating and associated low-level convergence inside the RMW can efficiently intensify the maximum winds. Outside the RMW, mid-level inflow associated with stratiform precipitation can efficiently spin-up the broader circulation through convergence of absolute angular momentum above the frictional boundary layer. The research will use existing research observations at different stages of the TC lifecycle from intensifying and non-intensifying storms to test these hypotheses. A new variational analysis technique called SAMURAI developed by the Principal Investigator will be used to integrate aircraft and radar observations into three-dimensional thermodynamic and kinematic fields for analysis. High-resolution Cartesian and low-wavenumber cylindrical analyses with improved radar thermodynamic retrievals will be conducted and augmented with numerical simulations to improve our understanding of TC intensification.

Broader Impacts:
This study integrates research and education by developing a new graduate radar meteorology course with a digital, interactive textbook, and incorporating mesoscale TC observations into physical meteorology curricula to train and encourage students to test scientific hypotheses using field observations. The open source SAMURAI analysis software and material from the digital radar meteorology textbook will be available to the atmospheric science community to enhance research and education infrastructure. The University of Hawaii at Manoa represents a demographically and geographically unique state in an EPSCoR jurisdiction, and the Principal Investigator is committed to improving diversity by including women and underrepresented minorities such as Pacific Islanders and Native Hawaiians in the project. Improvements in our understanding of TC intensity change can have a significant positive impact on society. The application of the findings from continued research on hurricanes and typhoons can ultimately help to improve our forecast ability and reduce life and property loss throughout the globe.

por.por_cntn:
This CAREER award investigated the processes that cause tropical cyclone (TC) intensification and heavy rainfall through analysis of atmospheric observations, theory, and numerical modeling. Forecasts of TC intensity change and heavy rainfall remain some of the most difficult weather predictions, but significant progress was made during the course of this NSF-supported research to improve our understanding of the physics and dynamics of these powerful storms. The improvements in our understanding of TCs from this research have a significant positive impact on society. The application of the findings from this research on hurricanes and typhoons will ultimately help to improve our forecast ability and reduce life and property loss throughout the globe.

One of the primary hypotheses of this research was that the convective character and location of precipitation within a storm relative to its wind field plays an important role in determining whether the storm will intensify or not. During the course of this research, this idea and related hypotheses were tested using field observations and numerical weather prediction models to diagnose the most important physical processes responsible for intensity change and weather impacts in order to improve forecasts. There were several major research activities conducted during this project, leading to multiple peer-reviewed publications supported by this funding. The research analyzed existing datasets from NSF-supported field experiments, including extensive use of data from the Hurricane Rainband and Intensity Change Experiment (RAINEX, 2005), Thorpex Pacific Area Regional Campaign (T-PARC, 2008), Hawaiian Educational Radar Opportunity (HERO, 2015), and Plains Elevated Convection at Night (PECAN, 2015) and other publicly-funded data from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) such as the Next-Generation radar network (NEXRAD) and Hurricane Hunter aircraft. The research resulted in the improvement of multiple open-source software tools freely available to the broader scientific community, including the development of a novel wind synthesis technique and new thermodynamic retrieval technique applicable in rapidly rotating vortices.

The primary outcomes of this project advanced our understanding of tropical convection and hurricanes, and have made significant progress towards the goal of determining where, when, and how precipitation will develop in different storms. Progress was made in better understanding of the structures of intensifying and weakening storms, tropical cyclogenesis, the convective structure of rainbands, eyewall replacement cycles, heavy rainfall, and extreme winds, as well as related collaborative research on thunderstorms, supercells, and squall lines. The research was presented at different domestic and international science conferences in addition to publication in the peer-reviewed literature to improve our collective, global scientific understanding and predictive capability of these high-impact weather phenomena. 

As a CAREER award, the project also integrated research and education by developing radar and tropical meteorology educational materials and incorporating NSF-supported field observations into atmospheric science curricula to train and encourage students to test scientific hypotheses using field observations. The funding supported multiple graduate students at the M.S. and Ph.D. level who will go on to become the next generation of atmospheric scientists in our field and continue to improve our understanding of hurricanes and other high-impact weather.
